findings.reasoning: The code follows the Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern correctly in _claimInterestFromManager. State is updated BEFORE the external call (positionAccountants[managerId].interestClaimedFromManager += interestAmount, totalInterestClaimed += interestAmount, pendingInterest += interestAmount, emit InterestClaimed) and THEN the external call is made (manager.withdraw(interestAmount)). This is the correct pattern to prevent reentrancy. The finding incorrectly claims the pattern is violated.

While the function does make external calls in a loop which can be gas-expensive, this is a view function. A DoS attack would require the attacker to be able to force others to call this function, which is not the case. The function is simply inefficient but not a security vulnerability. The code comment even acknowledges this: 'Note: This function makes external calls in a loop which can be gas-expensive'.

notes: The LLM's findings do not identify the target vulnerability described in the ground truth. The target vulnerability is in updatePositionManager/togglePositionManagerStatus functions where deactivating the default manager while auto-allocation is enabled causes allocation flows to revert. Neither finding mentions this issue or these functions.
